bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, September 12, 1940

div1.p: Hench introduces himself to Peabody by describing his interest in Lazear and the yellow fever experiments. He asks if Peabody would send him material that he has written on the subject.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, September 12, 1940
div1.opener:
September 12, 1940
Dr. James E. Peabody
152 Harvard Street
Newtonville, Massachusetts
My dear Doctor Peabody:
div1.p:
I have frequently heard of you through my friend, Mr. John R.
Kissinger, who has told me how wonderful you have been to him.

Washington and Jefferson College, Washington, Pennsylvania, is
dedicating a Lazear Memorial Building on October 26, and I have been asked to give
an address on the conquest of yellow fever. In preparation for this talk, I have
been delving into the history of this subject for a couple of years, and not only
visited Kissinger but also General Kean in Washington, Dr. Agramonte's daughter,
and John Moran in Havana. You will be interested to know that I have uncovered
some very important new information about the contribution of Lazear, and I hope
to publish this soon. I also found in Havana that the Cuban government had the
wrong site of Camp Lazear, upon which they already have a temporary memorial, and
have raised about $200,000 for a permanent memorial. Fortunately, Moran and I were
able to relocate the true site of the camp and I have been asked to make a formal
report to the Cuban government. In this connection, I would appreciate greatly if
I could get for permanent use, a copy of any material that you have published on
this subject, particularly the pamphlet, “The Conquest of Yellow Fever”. I wrote
to the American Museum of Natural History in New York but they could only lend me
one and I am anxious to keep it in my permanent file. If you have one, I would
appreciate it greatly.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
